results.title: Urban patterns
results.creator_credit: David Bairstow, Arch Nicholson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”
A study of the pattern of settlement in Australia, showing how the primacy of the major cities developed and how the economy continues to reinforce their dominance. For schools.

results.title: Urban mixtures
results.creator_credit: Peter Johnson, Martin Cohen and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontiers downunder”.
Four migrants talk about their adjustments to, and attitudes towards, Australian society. Although they are from different economic backgrounds, each has some involvement in migrant community, through social work, ethnic radio, and the ethnic community council.

results.title: Urban landscape
results.creator_credit: Peter Riding and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Exploring Photography”.
One of a series aimed to improve the viewers’ understanding of urban landscape photography as a creative medium and to increase their awareness of visual options. Several photographers discuss their aims and show their work. Narrated by Bryn Campbell.

results.title: Urban land use (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: John Radcliffe, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: Dr.J.Blunden discusses various attempts to analyse and quantify the spatial structure of urban zones, using Chicago as a primary illustration. In particular he considers E.W. Burgess and his concentric zone theory, and Homer Hoyts sectoral model, and both are integrated into a composite model.
results.description: Dr.J.Blunden discusses various attempts to analyse and quantify the spatial structure of urban zones, using Chicago as a primary illustration. In particular he considers E.W. Burgess and his concentric zone theory, and Homer Hoyts sectoral model, and both are integrated into a composite model.

results.title: Urban impact on weather and climate
results.brief_description: As man changes the surface of the earth through ever increasing urbanization there are corresponding changes in the weather and climate he must endure. Uses experimental models to show effects on rainfall, temperature, normal wind circulation and surface temperature, and the effects of pollutants. No other credits available.

results.title: Urban clan (A)
results.creator_credit: Film Finance Corporation Australia, MusicArtsDance Films, Paul Humfress, Aanya Whitehead and Michelle Mahrer
results.brief_description: The Page brothers - Stephen, Russell and David - are Aboriginal artists of mixed blood, part Maori, British and Aboriginal, whose talents were channelled into, (as choreographer, performer and composer respectively), the Sydney based Bangarra Dance company. In this informative documentary, made in 1997, before the untimely death of Russell, the brothers discuss their upbringing, experiences of racism, artistic desires, history and aspirations. Additionally, they visit the family home where they examine, with their parents, their ancestry, experiences of growing up in a white man’s world, and connection to the past. The brothers identify as nurturers to a culture under siege, and aim to keep the Dreamtime alive in a modern context, recognising the performances of Bangarra Dance Theatre as a modern day corroboree, storytelling in a contemporary form, that bridges urban Aboriginality with traditional beliefs, whilst promoting indigenous culture. Also features excerpts from the successful production of “Fish”, as well as rehearsals, and archival footage, stills and video, from the boys’ childhood. A fascinating portrait of one immensely talented family.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Finance Corporation Australia, MusicArtsDance Films, Paul Humfress, Aanya Whitehead and Michelle Mahrer

results.title: Urban Challenge
results.brief_description: Over-crowding and squalid living conditions have reached a crisis point in major cities in Third World Countries. This film examines the way in which governments and overseas aid agencies are meeting the challenge to improve living conditions for the cities’ poorer inhabitants.
results.description: Over-crowding and squalid living conditions have reached a crisis point in major cities in Third World Countries. This film examines the way in which governments and overseas aid agencies are meeting the challenge to improve living conditions for the cities’ poorer inhabitants.

results.title: Urban Aboriginal artists (A)
results.creator_credit: Christoph Willing, David Roberts, Peter Lipscombe and University of Sydney Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
While the three artists in this video cannot speak for all city-based Aboriginal artists, they raise issues central to the art-making of urban Aboriginals and the problems and controversies surrounding such art. They discuss issues of identity, their views on differences between black and white Australians and social issues of concern to their communities. Michael Riley has a growing reputation as a photographer and film maker, portraying the myths and misconceptions of Aboriginality. Trevor Nickolls has developed a strong iconography in his paintings which attempt to reconcile his black and white heritage. Jeffrey Samuels portrays his cultural heritage through his paintings using contemporary techniques, reflecting on stereotypes, tradition and nature.
